attributes.title: Six Contradicting Deviations from Rational Choice, and the Impact of Experience

q1.value: Six Contradicting Deviations from Rational Choice, and the Impact of Experience

q2.value: Ido Erev, Eyal Ert, Ori Plonsky, Yefim Roth

q3.value: The current research compares alternative models based on the accuracy of their predictions of the impact of experience in binary and 3-alternative choice tasks. The first part of our project shows that the results of 88 experimental conditions can be captured by three models. The preregistered study compares the predictions of these models by focusing on 80 randomly selected new experimental conditions. The three models compared are SAW, SAWx, and AOD described below, with the parameters chosen to best fit the training data. We predict that both SAW and SAWx will outperform AOD, but leave the relative comparison of the first two to be decided empirically.

q4.value:
The study compares three main quantitative hypotheses:
1.	Hypothesis SAW: Choice behavior reflects reliance on small samples, weighting of the average payoff, and some error.
2.	Hypothesis SAWx: Choice behavior reflects reliance on small samples, weighting of the average and the most extreme payoffs, and some error.
3.	Hypothesis AOD: Choice behavior reflects sensitivity to a running average of subjective values of the observed outcomes.  The subjective value decreases with similarity to other payoffs.

Detailed verbal description of each hypothesis is presented in the attached “6cHypotheses.docx” file.  In addition, the file “6cPredictions.csv” presents the quantitative point predictions implied by each hypothesis (the choice rates predicted by the relevant models for the 80 pre-registered conditions). The names of the variables are explained in the file “6cVariables.docx.”  We predict that both SAW and SAWx will outperform AOD, but leave the relative comparison of the first two to be decided empirically.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
To compare the hypotheses, we will run the 80 problems detailed in the attached “6cPredictions.csv” file.  The file “6cVariables.docx” explains the names of the variables. Each problem will be faced by 20 participants recruited using the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. Each participant will play one problem repeatedly for 100 trials using the clicking paradigm with full feedback (Erev and Haruvy, 2016; and see experiment screenshot in Figure1). 

Erev, I., & Haruvy, E. (2016). Learning and the economics of small decisions. The handbook of experimental economics, 2, 638-700.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
As explained above, each problem will be faced by 20 participants recruited using the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform (Mturk). Each participant will play one randomly selected problem repeatedly for 100 trials using the clicking paradigm with full feedback (Erev and Haruvy, 2016). Participants will be paid $1 for participating and an additional $0.5 bonus payment with probability that is contingent on their performance: the more points they accumulate, the more likely they will be to get the bonus. 
Each day, we are going to run 10 conditions. Each participant is allowed to participate in up to one condition per day. The experiment is going to be run on the weekdays (Monday – Friday). We restrict participation for 3 (English first language speaking) countries: USA, Canada, and England. The participants who will not complete the entire 100 trials will be excluded from the analysis. The experiments will be run online using the MTurk platform, thus there will be the possibility of fluctuation in the number of participants per condition. We are going to make sure that there are at least 20 participants per condition, but will not exclude any participants with complete data (i.e., participant that completed whole 100 trials).

The payoff distributions are points in a 16-dimension space.  That is, each task is determined by 16 task parameters, and involves a choice between 2 or 3 options. The tasks are presented in file "prereg6cont.csv", and the variables explanation is in file "6cVariables.docx"

The main analysis focuses on the choice rates of each option in 5 blocks of 20 trials.  The dependent variable for model comparison is the mean squared deviation (MSD) between the predicted and the observed choice rates of Option A and of Option B over the 80 problems (in the attached problems table), where the choice rates in each problem are computed in 5 blocks of 20 trials each (10 choice rates for each of the binary problems, and 15 rates for each of the 3-alternative problems). The best model is the one with the lowest MSD score.

Based on the MSD criteria, we will compare statistically the performance of the three models using a 95% bootstrapped confidence interval for the difference between the MSDs of the models. The bootstrap procedure will use 20000 replications and the CI will be constructed using the percentile method.

q21.value: 95% bootstrapped CI for the difference in MSD

q22.value: Participants who have not completed the whole experiment (i.e., 100 trials) will be entirely excluded from the data analysis.

q23.value: Participants with missing choice rates data will be entirely excluded from the data analysis.

attributes.title: Signals of adverse drug reactions communicated by pharmacovigilance stakeholders: protocol for a scoping review of the global literature

summary.value:
This registration concerns a protocol for a scoping review of the evidence underpinning signals of adverse drug reactions at a global level. Please see the attached files for the full protocol and the annex for the systematic search strategy (adapted to PubMed).

To the best of the authors' knowledge reviews of signals have not been carried out in a systematic way and have been restricted to classes of medicinal products, types of regulatory communications, language or periods of time. This would then be one of the largest exploratory studies aimed a synthesising the evidence of signals of adverse drug reactions and highlighting patterns of similarities and differences across multiple stakeholders in terms of timing and levels of evidence. Of note is the criterion for inclusion of records that explicitly mention the succesful detection of signals, as opposed to entrusting the determination of what does, or does not, constitute a signal in the hands of the authors of this scoping review; this is motivated by low interrater agreement scores between investigators who assess putative causal relationships between medicinal products and adverse events and by discrepancies in regulatory risk-minimisation actions, which reflect the subjective value judgments that take place in signal detection.

The protocol lays down the basis for a study that is envisioned to be disseminated by publication on a peer-reviewed journal and to be included in Daniele Sartori's DPhil thesis.

attributes.title: Patent valuation: toward a direct measurement

q1.value: Patent valuation: toward a direct measurement

q2.value: Albina Khairullina, Christopher Tucci, Neil Thompson

q3.value: This project seeks to understand the effects of patent protection on the commercial outcomes of products that incorporate the patented innovations.  We collaborate with a large multinational company to analyze confidential internal data on product sales, revenues, and other corporate performance.  To establish causality, we run a randomized controlled trial in which randomly-chosen patents are moved into the public domain, while others retain patent protection. To our knowledge, this is the first study that conducts a randomized controlled trial to measure the real market effect of patent protection.

q4.value:
H0: Abandoning a patent has no effect on the market performance of related products (sales, price, units sold, or market share)
H1: Abandoning a patent has a positive or negative effect on the market performance of related products (sales, price, units sold or market share)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This project aims to understand whether firms should patent more or less, and thus considers patents on the decision boundary – that is, those patents ‘on the margin’, including neither those that are clearly worthless (and should be abandoned), nor those that are extremely valuable (and thus should be maintained).  A set of such patents, identified in collaboration with our commercial partner, form the at-risk set.
The at-risk set is divided into blocks according to the patent being covered and the characteristics of the country of that coverage.  For example, two patents might be in the same block if they are part of the same patent family (i.e. cover the same invention in different countries) and if the countries that they cover are similar in terms of GDP per capita.   Within each block, we do complete randomization, with the patent coverage in treatment countries being maintained while patent coverage in control countries is abandoned.
In each country, we examine the commercial outcomes of all products that the patent applies to.  Thus our variation is cross-country, within-patent.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: We have only analyzed pre-treatment data, which we used to do power calculations.  We have not analyzed nor seen any post-treatment data.

question.value: Data for our experiment comes from our commercial partner, who has this administrative data in its records.  Depending on the geography that a particular patent applies to, the frequency and depth of the commercial outcomes vary.

q13.value: Our analysis includes 29 patents, spanning 7 patent families, 13 countries and 15 products.  One patent family may need to be excluded if post-treatment data is not available.

q14.value:
The sample size was determined endogenously, based on quarterly reviews by the company of patents that met our inclusion criteria.

We confirmed that our sample size would be sufficient through a power analysis, where we examined possible treatment effects ranging from 0 to 2 standard deviations of the corresponding performance indicator.  Based on bootstrap simulations, we determined that current sample sizes provide statistical power of 80% with treatment sizes of a least 0.2 standard deviations at a significance level of 5%.

q15.value: Sample size was capped based on the willingness of the commercial partner to continue experimenting.

question.value: Whether patent protection is renewed or abandoned in each country.

Units = how many units of particular products are sold in each month / quarter / year 
 	Revenue = revenue from a product in that time period
 	Market share (revenue) = a fraction of the company’s revenues relative to competitors’ revenue
 	Market share (units) = a fraction of the company’s units relative to competitors’ units 
 	Price = average retail price of units sold
 	Competitors’ Units = how many units sold in each relevant period (monthly or annually) by competing parties for the product related to the patent in question  
 	Competitors’ Revenue = revenue from rival products in the market from competitors
In all cases, we normalize data (pre and post) by pre-treatment mean and standard deviations, so that data in each period is a deviation away from the pre-treatment mean, expressed as a number of standard deviations.  Pre- and post-periods are also collapsed into single values, e.g. Average(Revenue_pre) , to allow for aggregation over various reporting periods / consistency.  Values across products within a country are weighted using their revenue share.

Based on our power analysis, some regressions may include block fixed effects, or block effects, country and product fixed effects, in order to maximize power.
As described in Measured Variables above

We analyze our data using simple comparisons of means and using a differences-in-differences regression estimator:
Y_(i,post)=Y_(i,pre)+τ_i+block_b+country_c+product_p
Where Y_i is the outcome variable, τ is the treatment indicator.  Block, country, and product are fixed effects that will be added iteratively in robustness tests.
Regressions are weighted by product revenue. In other words, products that represent a more important element of a country’s portfolio are given more weight when aggregating to the country level.

q20.value: We attempt to look at changes from the average value of each performance indicator, regardless of scale.  They are normalized based on pre-treatment data (as described in Measured Variables, above)

q21.value: We will consider standard statistical significance cutoffs .10, .05, .01, .001, using two-sided regression coefficient significance tests.

q22.value: Data will be excluded if outcome data cannot be obtained, or if the randomization protocol was not adhered to.

q23.value: If data are completely missing, such that our key variables cannot be generated, we will exclude that observation.  If data are at least partially there, we will create pre- and post- averages using the data that are available.

q24.value: Characteristics of products, countries, and patent coverage of particular products.  E.g., if we know that a product is completely covered by one patent vs for example five patents.

attributes.title: The effect of heightened self-awareness on emotions following failure
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: Since data collection will probably not end before May 2020, and since the study is conducted in the context of a master thesis, data might be evaluated earlier than expected (N=153).

dataCollectionDates.value:
The project started in February 2020.
Data collection should end in October 2020.

question2a.value:
a.	whether they are within- or between-participants 
Self-awareness and failure will be manipulated orthogonally in a 2x2 between participant design.
b.	the relationship between them (e.g., orthogonal, nested).
These IV will be orthogonally manipulated

question2b.value: We will assess reported state shame as the main dependent variable.

question3b.value:
No covariates.
We predict an interaction between self-awareness and failure on reported state shame.

question10b.value:
Participants will be greeted and led to the experimental room. They will be sat in front of a computer. After being briefed by the experimenter, they will follow instructions displayed on the computer screen.
First, they will be asked to do an emotion recognition task: neutral/ambiguous faces will be displayed on the screen and they will be instructed to decide what emotion the person displayed on the screen is mainly feeling (joy, sadness, contempt, disappointment, anger, disgust). After each trial, participants will receive a bogus feedback indicating either “Correct” or “Incorrect”. In the failure condition, participants will receive 70% incorrect feedbacks and 30% correct feedbacks. In contrast, participants in the control condition will receive 70% correct feedbacks and 30% incorrect feedbacks.
After this task, participants will have to complete the SSGS (Marschall, Sanftner, & Tangney, 1994), a scale assessing state shame, state guilt and state pride.
Once the SSGS completed, participants will be asked to answer to the two questions assessing the efficiency of the manipulation, namely: “What is your estimation of the rate of correct answers in the first task of the study?” (on a scale from 0 to 100) and “Do you consider this performance to be more of a success or more of a failure?” (categorical choice between “success” and “failure”

question4b.value: Participants will be native French speakers.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from psychology students in exchange for course credits.

question6b.value: We will collect from 200 participants as a result of the limited amount of course credits available.

question7b.value: Data collection will stop after the 200th participant.

question8b.value: Participants associated to scores greater than 2.5 MAD from the median will be excluded from our sample pairwise.

question7c.value: Since data collection will be made via a computer, missing data will be nearly impossible. However, if a participant exits the experiment before the completion of all the measures, s/he will be excluded from our sample pairwise.

question8c.value: A confirmatory factor analysis should be computed on the SSGS to assess if the items do reflect the three expected dimensions (i.e., shame, guilt, pride). If an item fail to represent the expected dimension, it should be excluded from our analyses.

question10c.value: If the distribution of guilt-free shame scores’ residuals differs significantly from normality (as assessed by a Shapiro-Wilks test), we should use a non-parametric alternative such as a Mann- Whitney test.

question1a.value:
Main Hypothesis: Heightened self-awareness during the experience of a failure will result on greater reported shame
Secondary hypothesis:  Main effects of self-awareness and failure should independently influence reported shame

question2a.value: Following a failure, participants should report feeling more shame than in a control condition. Self-awareness should positively moderate this effect so that this effect of failure on shame should be greater when participants are made to be self-aware.

question3a.value: The success of our manipulation will be estimated by two manipulation check at the end of the study, namely two questions assessing that participants did perceive a failure or a success during their performance. The two questions are described in section B.10.

question5a.value:
Self-awareness alone suffices to increase escape-thought accessibility (Selimbegović & Chatard, 2013). We can hypothesize that this effect can be explained by a possible main effect of self-awareness on negative emotions. For this reason, main effect of self-awareness will be tested on reported guilt-free shame and reported shame-free guilt (see section C.1).
Shame and guilt are both emotions closely related to an experience of failure. However, shame is an emotion that should result from a negative evaluation of the self (“I am bad”) whereas guilt should result from a negative evaluation of a behavior (“I did something bad”). Consequently, we hypothesize that the interaction failure x self-awareness should increase the attribution of a failure on the self and therefore felt shame should be higher (comparatively to felt guilt).

question1c.value: We will compute a shame, a guilt, and a pride score with the SSGS. We will then compute a guilt-free shame score by regressing the guilt score on shame and saving the residuals associated to this regression (i.e. the proportion of variance of shame that is not explained by guilt). The reverse will be done to compute a shame-free guilt score.

question2c.value: We will use a linear regression model to assess the effect of the failure induction, the effect of self-awareness, and their interaction on guilt-free shame score.

registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: If the distribution of guilt-free shame scores’ residuals differs significantly from normality (as assessed by a Shapiro-Wilks test), we should use a non-parametric alternative such as a Mann- Whitney test.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants will be greeted and led to the experimental room. They will be sat in front of a computer. After being briefed by the experimenter, they will follow instructions displayed on the computer screen.
First, they will be asked to do an emotion recognition task: neutral/ambiguous faces will be displayed on the screen and they will be instructed to decide what emotion the person displayed on the screen is mainly feeling (joy, sadness, contempt, disappointment, anger, disgust). After each trial, participants will receive a bogus feedback indicating either “Correct” or “Incorrect”. In the failure condition, participants will receive 70% incorrect feedbacks and 30% correct feedbacks. In contrast, participants in the control condition will receive 70% correct feedbacks and 30% incorrect feedbacks.
After this task, participants will have to complete the SSGS (Marschall, Sanftner, & Tangney, 1994), a scale assessing state shame, state guilt and state pride.
Once the SSGS completed, participants will be asked to answer to the two questions assessing the efficiency of the manipulation, namely: “What is your estimation of the rate of correct answers in the first task of the study?” (on a scale from 0 to 100) and “Do you consider this performance to be more of a success or more of a failure?” (categorical choice between “success” and “failure”
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: We will compute a shame, a guilt, and a pride score with the SSGS. We will then compute a guilt-free shame score by regressing the guilt score on shame and saving the residuals associated to this regression (i.e. the proportion of variance of shame that is not explained by guilt). The reverse will be done to compute a shame-free guilt score.
We will use a linear regression model to assess the effect of the failure induction, the effect of self-awareness, and their interaction on guilt-free shame score.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants will be native French speakers.
Data will be collected from psychology students in exchange for course credits.
We will collect from 200 participants as a result of the limited amount of course credits available.
Data collection will stop after the 200th participant.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Participants associated to scores greater than 2.5 MAD from the median will be excluded from our sample pairwise.

attributes.title: Well-being of Grandparents Raising Grandchildren: A Global Systematic Review Protocol

q1.value: Well-being of Grandparents Raising Grandchildren: A Global Systematic Review

q2.value: Athena C. Y. Chan, Jingchen Zhang, Sun-Kyung Lee, Jasmine Banegas, Scott Marsalis, Abigail Gewirtz

q3.value:
Rationale:
Grandparents play a universal role in family life, providing emotional support and practical care to their children and grandchildren (Hayslip, Fruhauf, & Dolbin-MacNab, 2017; Stelle, Fruhauf, Orel, & Landry-Meyer, 2010). With improved longevity and changes in family structure, grandparents are fulfilling more family functions while the multigenerational bond becomes “a valuable new resource for families in the 21st century” (Bengtson, 2001). Specifically, higher rates of dual-income household, parental divorce and separation, and parent’s physical/mental health conditions create the need for active grandparenthood. Grandparents play important roles in sharing parenting responsibilities within single-parent families, intergenerational co-parenting families, or skipped generation families (Brandon, 2012; Chen, Liu, & Mair, 2011; Keene & Batson, 2010). In view of the diversified family compositions, grandparental care in multigenerational families is crucial to the well-being and development of grandchildren and grandparent over their life course.
A recent systematic review focuses on how grandparents raising grandchildren has an impact over the health and development of grandchildren (Sadruddin et al. 2019). However, little is known how it affects the well-being of grandparent caregivers (Grinstead, Leder, Jensen & Bond, 2003; Hadfield, 2014; Hayslip & Kaminski, 2005). Further, it is unclear how different factors, such as family structure, perceived social support, and sociocultural context play a role in the association between  grandparenting and the well-being of grandparent caregivers. We will systematically review the characteristics of grandparents raising grandchildren and how it affects the physical and/or mental well-being of grandparents. In the context of an aging society, this systematic review provides a timely understanding of the impact of caregiving on the well-being of grandparent caregivers.

Objectives:
The aim of this systematic review is to identify global studies examining the association between grandparents raising grandchildren and the physical and/or mental well-being of grandparents. The proposed systematic review will answer the following questions:
1.     How does the involvement (i.e., contact, caregiving behavior, and support) of grandparents in grandchildren influence elder’s physical and/or mental health (well-being)?
2.     What level of evidence exists that family factors (i.e., caregiving role and intensity, co-residence, resources, relationship and communication) play a role in the relationship between grandparent involvement of grandchildren and elder’s health?
3. What level of evidence exists that cultural factors (i.e., geographical location, ethnicity/race) play a role in the relationship between grandparent involvement of grandchildren and elder’s health?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will systematically review articles examining the association of grandparents raising grandchildren and the well-being of grandchildren in relevance to the family and sociocultural factors. Peer-reviewed articles on quantitative studies published after 1990 will be included.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Search Strategy:
Peer-reviewed articles published in English, Chinese, Korean, and Spanish will be included, as these are spoken by team members and resources limit our ability for additional translation. We will include empirical studies published in peer-reviewed journal articles 1990-2020 (by February) . We will not be limited by geography. The specific search strategies for each database will be designed by the research team in collaboration with a Social Sciences Librarian with expertise in systematic review searching. The draft search strategy is included as Appendix 1.

Information sources:
We will search four online databases for peer-reviewed published articles. Databases to be searched: PsycInfo (Ovid), Medline (Ovid), CINAHL (Proquest), Scopus.

question.value:
Eligibility Criteria
1.  Year of publication: In view of the ageing concerns in the United Nations, peer-reviewed articles published after 1990 will be included.
2.  Publication type: Peer-reviewed journal articles will be included
3. Language: Studies in English, Chinese, Korean, and Spanish will be included, as these are spoken by team members.
4. Study Design: All quantitative studies (including association, longitudinal, intervention/experimental studies) will be included. 
5. Participants: Grandparents involved in formal/ informal caregiving of grandchildren aged between 0 and 18. 
6. Outcomes: Studies reporting well-being broadly defined as physical and/or mental health of grandparent caregivers. 

Exclusion criteria:
1.  All grey literature (i.e., book chapter, conference abstract and dissertation) will be excluded.
2.  Peer-reviewed journal articles which are not published in one of the following languages: English, Chinese, Korean, and Spanish.
3.  Articles on qualitative studies will be excluded.
4.  Articles reporting only child-related outcomes will be excluded.
5. Articles reporting only elders’ wellbeing but no mention of their caregiving roles will be excluded. 
 
Study Records
Literature search results will be imported into Covidence, an Internet based software program that supports deduplication, collaboration among reviewers during the screening process, and the creation of a PRISMA flow diagram upon screening completion. Automatic and manual de-duplication will be conducted in Covidence.
All reviewers will be trained on the Covidence software by a librarian with experience in this software. The screening criteria will be piloted by having all reviewers screen a subset of abstracts; this process will be used to refine the criteria and establish consensus among reviewers. Individual reviewers will then code abstracts and full text articles; Covidence will record their decisions allowing reliability to be calculated.
 
Selection process.
All screeners participated in the development of the review aims and inclusion/exclusion criteria; they have equal familiarity with the study goals and screening process. Reviewers will independently apply our inclusion criteria to the titles and abstracts included in the search results. Each reviewer will be randomly assigned to screen particular abstracts using Covidence software available online. Each abstract will be reviewed by at least two reviewers; disagreements will be recorded and resolved by group discussion. Reviewers will then screen full text articles and seek information from study authors if further information is needed in order to determine whether a study meets the inclusion criteria. Disagreements will be recorded and resolved through discussion. All exclusions during abstract and full text screening will be recorded. Reviewers will have access to all publication information during screening, including journal titles and study authors and institutions.

Data Collection Process.
Data will be extracted from included articles using a standardized form. Piloting of data extraction forms will be conducted prior to the formal process in order to establish consensus among team members. Two reviewers will extract all data and check for agreement; we will contact study authors a maximum of three times when further information is needed. Disagreements on any data will be resolved through discussion with a third member of the team.

Data items.
The standardized data extraction form will include variables of interest: year of publication, study location/language, sample size, grandparent characteristics (e.g., ethnicity/race, gender, age, caregiver role, etc), grandchildren characteristics (e.g., age, gender, co-residence status, duration of stay, and health condition), family characteristics (e.g., family support, family relationship, communication, and family structure), sociocultural context (e.g., geographical location, race/ethnicity and culture), primary outcome measures (e.g., grandparents’ physical health, mental health, perceived stress, resilience, well-being and life satisfaction).

Risk of bias in individual studies.
The quality and risk of bias of articles are assessed using a checklist of 14 items adapted from an established quality assessment of quantitative studies (Kmet, Cook, & Lee, 2004). See Appendix 2. This ensures the included quantitative studies are of reasonable quality in terms of  research objectives, study design, analytical method, results reporting, and conclusion supported by results. The evaluation process will be performed independently by two researchers and meetings will be held to resolve disagreement. Studies will be categorized as high, moderate or low quality in terms of meeting the number of criteria.
Not applicable.

Grandparent characteristics, grandchildren characteristics, family characteristics, sociocultural context, grandparents’ well-being (i.e., physical health, mental health, perceived stress, resilience, and life satisfaction).
Not applicable.

Data synthesis.
The planned analysis will include two parts. The first narrative synthesis will tabulate the included studies with respect to geographic location, study design, sample characteristics, context of grandparental care, living arrangement, resources and support, as well as grandparent outcomes. The second part of analysis will evaluate the contribution and intersection of family factors (i.e., grandparental caregiver role and family support) and cultural factors (i.e., geographical location and ethnicity/races of grandparents) that potentially influence the heterogeneity of grandparent care and their well-being. 

Analysis Plan.
Table 1- General characteristics of the study and sample 
Table 2 - Synthesis of findings by family factors 
Table 3 - Synthesis of findings by cultural factors

The first narrative synthesis will tabulate the included studies with respect to geographic location, study design, sample characteristics, context of grandparental care, living arrangement, resources and support, as well as grandparent outcomes. The second part of analysis will evaluate the contribution and intersection of family factors (i.e., grandparental caregiver role and family support) and cultural factors (i.e., geographical location and ethnicity/races of grandparents) that potentially influence the heterogeneity of grandparent care and their well-being. 

Analysis Plan.
Table 1- General characteristics of the study and sample 
Table 2 - Synthesis of findings by family factors 
Table 3 - Synthesis of findings by cultural factors

3. In a lake, there is a patch of lily pads. Every day, the patch doubles in size. If it takes 48 days for the patch to cover the entire lake, how long would it take for the patch to cover half the lake? ____ days
4. If you are running a race and you pass the person in second place, what place are you in? ____ place
5. A farmer had 15 sheep and all but 8 died. How many are left? _____ sheep
6. . Emily's father has three daughters. The first two are named April and May. What is the third daughter's name?
7. How many cubic feet of dirt are there in a hole that is 3' deep x 3' wide x 3' long?

CRT scores will be computed by summing the number of correct responses to these 7 questions.

3. To what extent do you believe that the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is a hoax? (1 = definitely not a hoax, 6 = definitely a hoax).

name.value: Structure and Punitive Judgments: COVID manipulation

sample.value: We will collect data from 1300 participants on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
We will first compute a linear mixed-effects model (LMEM) with personal need for structure (based on the 11-item scale developed by Neuberg and Newsom, 1993) and cooperation salience as fixed-effects, and with punishment judgments as the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects (random intercepts only). We may also average across all punishment ratings to compute standard multiple regressions.

Then, we will compute two follow-up LMEMs: one for the experimental condition only, and the other for the control condition only. In each model, PNS will be the fixed-effect, and punishment judgments will be the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects. We may also compute two analogous follow-up multiple regressions where we average across punishment ratings so that random effects are not needed.

Finally, we will conduct a simple slopes analysis in the original fitted models. We will test whether, at low levels of PNS (-1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero. And we will test whether, at high levels of PNS (+1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero.

outliers.value: The study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value: Participants will be presented with 12 moral principles, and for each one they will report how much a person who violates the principle should be punished on a 6-pt scale (1 = not at all, 6 = very much).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions in a between-subjects fashion. We will manipulate the salience of the need for cooperation and dependency on one's community. To do so, participants randomly assigned to the experimental condition will be asked to think about and write about how cooperation between people in their communities is important for properly responding to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. Participants in the control condition will not be asked to think about or write about anything.

hypothesis.value: Is it the case that making salient the need for cooperation during the COVID-19 pandemic moderates the relationship between the personal need for structure and punitive judgments for moral principle violators?

attributes.title: Clinical Supervision: A potential strategy to improve implementation climate

q1.value: Clinical Supervision: A Potential Strategy to Improve Implementation Climate

q4.value:
Primary Hypotheses:

We hypothesize that evidence-based treatment (EBT) focused supervision (i.e., Symptom and Fidelity Monitoring (SFM) + Behavioral Rehearsal (BR) or SFM only) is positively associated with clinicians’ shared perception of their organization’s EBT implementation climate compared to supervision as usual. 

Moderator:
We hypothesize that clinicians’ shared perceptions of organizational climate will moderate the effect of supervision type (gold standard supervision vs. supervision as usual) on EBT implementation climate. More specifically, the relationship between supervision type and implementation climate is hypothesized to be significantly more positive when organizational climate is high (vs. low). 

Secondary Hypothesis:
We hypothesize that evidence-based treatment (EBT) focused supervision (i.e., Symptom and Fidelity Monitoring (SFM) + Behavioral Rehearsal (BR) or SFM only) is positively associated with clinicians’  individual perceptions of their organization’s EBT implementation climate compared to supervision as usual.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: This study is a secondary data analysis. Our data comes from a two-phase, mixed within- and between- subjects design studying supervision of an EBT for child trauma exposure sequelae, Trauma-focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT). The parent study leverages the Washington State TF-CBT Initiative to examine clinical supervision practices and assess the impact of gold standard supervision strategies (i.e., symptom and fidelity monitoring (SFM) and behavioral rehearsal (BR)) on treatment fidelity and clinical outcomes. In Phase I, descriptive statistics of supervision practices are conducted. In Phase II, clinicians are randomized to one of two gold standard clinical supervision practices: SFM + BR or SFM only. Self-report measures were administered at the beginning of Phase I, the beginning of Phase II, and at 1 year follow-up post-intervention in Phase II. This present study will only use data from Phase II of the parent study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The primary author of this study does not currently have access to any of the data. The primary investigator, that has the collected data of the parent study, will not provide the data to this author to analyze until the pre-registration is completed. Moreover, this current study’s research question and hypotheses have not been examined by the primary investigator or any researcher.

question.value: Study participants are supervisors and clinicians that were selected from agencies that were part of WA TF-CBT Initiative. Eligible clinicians had to be trained in TF-CBT as part of the WA TF-CBT Initiative and/or have completed the TF-CBT web training with at least one TF-CBT case underway, at least 50% FTE employees at one of the participating agencies, supervised by a participating supervisor, and able to provide TF-CBT in English.  Exclusion criteria include immediate plans to leave the agency or transition into a non-child/adolescent caseload carrying position. Clinicians and supervisors completed self-report study measures via a web-based survey at the Phase I baseline, Phase II baseline, and Phase II 1-year follow-up. Supervisors received $30 or $40 gift cards (depending on when they were enrolled) whereas clinicians received $30 gift cards for their time to complete the surveys.

q13.value: Sample size of this study will be determined by number of clinicians that participated in Phase II of the parent study that completed implementation climate measures (our primary outcome variable). Clinicians are the unit of randomization and they are clustered within supervisors at their organization to account for the multi-level nature of our data.

question.value:
The key dependent variable is Implementation Climate: Clinician-reported EBT implementation climate was measured using the Evidence-Based Organizational Checklist, a 6-item questionnaire used to evaluate the degree to which organizations expect, support, and reward EBT use. The items on the questionnaire were rated on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (Never) to 4 (Ongoing/Routine), which included items such as “Clinicians are provided with EBP training opportunities and access to EBP materials.” Mean scores on this measure were obtained for each clinician and then aggregated at the supervisor level (i.e., supervisory team) due to the 2-level nature of the study and the theory that supervisors play a critical role in conveying an organization’s implementation climate to clinicians. Higher scores indicate a more positive EBT implementation climate. 

Other included covariates include:
Organizational climate: clinician-reported organizational climate was measured using sub-scales from the Texas Christian University Organizational Readiness for Change (TCU-ORC) which is a "comprehensive assessment of organizational functioning and readiness for change." The three sub-scales we are using are organizational stress, cohesion, and communication. The items on the questionnaire were rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (Disagree Strongly) to 5 (Agree Strongly). Higher scores indicate a more positive organizational climate.

Self-Efficacy in Supervising: supervisor-report level of competency across a variety of supervision activities is measured via items developed as part of pre-work survey for Project TF-CBT New Jersey. Items include self-reported competence in identifying cases, supervising clinicians on TF-CBT components, encouraging the use of TF-CBT components, and adapting across situations. The items were rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (Not at all) Strongly) to 5 (Exceptionally). An example of an item is, "Encourage use of TF-CBT by clinicians who are new or wary." Higher scores indicate higher self-efficacy in supervising. 

Other covariates include: assigned condition (SFM + BR vs. SFM only), clinicians’ years employed by current organization, client caseload, and number of supervisees.

We plan to assess the relationship between gold standard supervision practices that focus on EBTs and organizational EBT implementation climate (clinicians’ aggregate scores) using a 2-level multilevel model (MLM) with random effects at the supervisor level due to the clustered nature of clinicians within supervisors.
 
Organizational climate will be examined as a moderator for the effect of supervision type (gold standard vs. supervision as usual) on organizational EBT implementation climate using a 2-level MLM with random effects at the supervisor level due to the clustered nature of clinicians within supervisors. 
 
We will also assess the relationship between gold standard supervision practices that focus on EBTs and clinicians’ individual perceptions of EBT implementation climate using a 2-level multilevel model (MLM) with random effects at the supervisor level due to the clustered nature of clinicians within supervisors. 
 
Covariates in our MLMs:

At Level 1 we will include clinician-related factors: study condition (SFM + BR or SFM only), clinicians’ years employed by current organization, client caseload

At level 2 we will include supervisor-related factors: organizational climate, number of supervisees, and self-efficacy in supervising
